awd_titl_txt: CNS: Collaborative Research: EAGER: From Computer Networks to Food Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
With food sourced from every part of the country and from around the world, food supply chains are extremely complex pathways from farm to the table. Unfortunately, up to 20-30% of the fresh food is spoiled by the time it reaches the customer in US, and a similar amount is further thrown away by the customers at least partly due to lack of freshness. Thus, understanding food networks and devising mechanisms to reduce losses can have huge economic and environmental impact. The purpose of this project is to understand and improve food distribution networks by applying and extending techniques from the science of computer networking, which can handle tremendous amounts of complexity beyond the scales seen in food networks. The unique characteristics of food networks will require significant innovations beyond the state of the art in computer networking and thus will provide valuable results for novel and emerging complex computer networks as well.
 
The design and optimization of a "food network" poses many challenges and requires innovations that are expected to benefit both food networks and computer networks. In particular, food network involve unique 'rotting packets' (continuous decrease in quality of the package contents), a demand-driven and quality-centric delivery and distribution, in-network bundling/unbundling of 'packets', mixing of a large variety of 'payloads', and dynamic changes to packet sources and types. The purpose of this proposal is to address these challenges and lay the foundation for a systematic design and operation of food networks. Since many of these challenges are relevant to computer networks as well, the proposed work will consider them in that context as well. In particular, the research will examine issues relating to in-network bundling/unbundling of packets, content based (rather than address based) routing/distribution, QoS aware forwarding of multi-modal data, and disruption tolerant operation. The research will also allow for better management of the food networks in the face of emerging trends in maximal utilization of seasonal and local foods which requires significant flexibility and dynamic configurability in the food sourcing and distribution networks.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to study parallels between the food distribution and computer networks and thereby develop techniques that will advance both fields. 

In terms of intellectual merit, we have been able to show that there are significant areas of both convergence and differences between the logistics and computer network fields, and this had led to our follow on inspire project. In particular, we have identified several specific areas of synergy and developed some techniques already. In particular, we have observed close similarities between the twin problems of (a) integration of long-distance and regional logistics for fresh food, and (b) integration of long-distance transport of information and its local distribution (last mile problem). This inspired us to develop a hybrid optical-electrical data center network proposal published in Local Computer Networks (LCN) 2015. Similarly, we observed that the content centric networking that is currently being examined in computer networks has lessons for fresh food distribution, particularly the so called “lateral distribution” of fresh food to cope with perishability. This inspired us to design locality aware content centric distribution networks for both areas. These are currently under development. Many other areas of synergy were also observed (e.g., virtualization) and are currently under development. In short, we believe that this EAGER grant (which supported one post-doctoral candidate for one year) richly served its purpose of examining the synergies between the two fields, and has put us on the path to investigate many issues on both logistics and computer network side.

In terms of broader impact, the project allowed us to be plugged into the "Physical Internet" initiative that attempts to bring a set of standards for identification of physical entities (packages, containers, trucks, warehouses, etc.), for their sizing (so called Physical Internet or PI containers), and sharing of capacity via third party logistics (3PL). The Physical Internet initiative as it stands is focused on the overall logistics problem of all types of goods and does not consider perishability directly. (Some aspects of perishability are covered by the delivery time contracts.) Since perishability is an essential aspect of fresh food transport logistics; we have been successful in bringing this aspect to the attention of PI community and working with them. In particular, we presented two papers at the recent IPIC (International Physical Internet Conference) in Atlanta on perishable food logistics and the connections with new developments in Internet (e.g., CCN). We expect to influence PI initiative more strongly in the perishability area in the future as a result of the EAGER grant.
